author.bio_html:

body:
We added "don't index this page" and "don't follow this link" metadata in more places to better assist users with private mode enabled. As demonstrated, for example, [here](https://ruqqus.com/post/2ewm/serious-problem-with-private-profiles), people could use clever searches to effectively bypass private profile mode.

By asking search engines to not index content by users with private mode enabled, this problem should be fixed.

Note that it will take several days to several weeks for this to fully take effect, as we cannot do anything about existing indexed content until the next time the search engine happens to crawl those pages.
body_html:
We added "don't index this page" and "don't follow this link" metadata in more places to better assist users with private mode enabled. As demonstrated, for example, here, people could use clever searches to effectively bypass private profile mode.

By asking search engines to not index content by users with private mode enabled, this problem should be fixed.

Note that it will take several days to several weeks for this to fully take effect, as we cannot do anything about existing indexed content until the next time the search engine happens to crawl those pages.
title: Patch 2.17.9 - Search engine metadata and private mode

body:
There should be an option within private profile:

Hide posts and comments on the profile page (but still be indexed by search engines)

Hide posts and comments on the profile page (& do not be indexed by search engines)

If more users allow their content to be indexed by search engines it will help the platform grow. The basic private profile mode would stop all but the most determined people from going through and downrepping the entire profile anyway. If they want more anonymity then they can select the more restrictive mode. 

Let the user choose.
body_html:
There should be an option within private profile:

Hide posts and comments on the profile page (but still be indexed by search engines)

Hide posts and comments on the profile page (& do not be indexed by search engines)

If more users allow their content to be indexed by search engines it will help the platform grow. The basic private profile mode would stop all but the most determined people from going through and downrepping the entire profile anyway. If they want more anonymity then they can select the more restrictive mode.

Let the user choose.

post.body_html:
We added "don't index this page" and "don't follow this link" metadata in more places to better assist users with private mode enabled. As demonstrated, for example, here, people could use clever searches to effectively bypass private profile mode.

By asking search engines to not index content by users with private mode enabled, this problem should be fixed.

Note that it will take several days to several weeks for this to fully take effect, as we cannot do anything about existing indexed content until the next time the search engine happens to crawl those pages.
post.title: Patch 2.17.9 - Search engine metadata and private mode

body: No, the presence of a "don't index this page" is based on the main content link. So the post for a post permalink, or a comment for a comment permalink. Other comments on the page are not considered.
body_html: No, the presence of a "don't index this page" is based on the main content link. So the post for a post permalink, or a comment for a comment permalink. Other comments on the page are not considered.

parent.body:
Shouldn't this eventually make all pages 'private' on Ruqqus? Let's say, one person in a thread has private profile, but all the other 10 comments are from public profiles. Does this make the entire page non-indexable?

My relevant comment from a few weeks ago: https://ruqqus.com/post/1i73/stopping-search-engines-from-listing-ruqqus/4qqq

By asking search engines to not index content by users with private mode enabled, this problem should be fixed.

Note that it will take several days to several weeks for this to fully take effect, as we cannot do anything about existing indexed content until the next time the search engine happens to crawl those pages.
